title: 113_s274
content: The "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act" is the short title of the legislation. It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Children Eating Well Act" defines terms such as elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, and State educational agency according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also defines "programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education" as initiatives that enhance students' ability to choose and consume healthy foods. Nutrition education programs aim to increase students' ability to choose and consume healthy foods, reflect various influences on healthy eating, prepare students for making healthy choices as adults, and use scientifically sound nutritional materials and methods. Nutrition education programs focus on teaching students to make healthy eating decisions as adults using scientifically sound and developmentally appropriate methods and materials supported by the most recent Dietary Guidelines for Americans. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of professional development programs for teachers, school staff, and food service workers to effectively teach healthy eating and nutrition, in line with the Dietary Guidelines for Americans. Programs are established to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. Local educational agencies receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in all schools served by the agency. This may include integrating such programs into various activities. Local educational agencies must integrate programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, emphasizing knowledge and appreciation of healthy foods, especially fresh fruits and vegetables. The curr_chunk emphasizes knowledge and appreciation of healthy foods, balanced diet and lifestyle, integration of healthy eating with physical activity, and various wellness activities for students. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting healthy eating habits, integrating physical activity, and implementing wellness activities for students without emphasizing weight loss. Local educational agencies must consult various viewpoints in developing these initiatives. The curr_chunk emphasizes consulting multiple viewpoints to develop programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education among students. The curr_chunk highlights the importance of collaborating with various organizations with nutrition education expertise to develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of collaborating with organizations and government authorities to develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. The curr_chunk focuses on agencies providing technical assistance for designing programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, working with wellness councils, and integrating programs for healthy eating. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of collaborating with school health advisory groups to develop, implement, and evaluate programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. It also highlights the integration of these programs with the local school wellness policy and the provision of professional development including nutrition education for staff members. The curr_chunk emphasizes state requirements for promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, including submitting periodic reports to the Secretary of Education. This includes monitoring data collected from local educational agencies. The Secretary of Education must submit periodic reports on programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education, including monitoring data from local educational agencies. An inter-agency task force will review nutrition education curricula and recommend effective programs for schools. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for nutrition education programs in schools for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
